page.title: 05The Gt.Orme -Grassland
page.content: {Sheep's Fescue}grows abundantly in this habitat and is grazed by sheep. Amongst it in the summer one can see the yellow flowers of the common{Rock {Rose}and{Cowslip,}the{Salad Burnet, which has a round green head but no petals, the purple headed{Bloody {Cranesbill}and the pink{Pyramidal {Orchid.}The short stemmed, yellow- brown{Carline Thistle}is also abundant. Two sub-species of butterfly are common to the Great Orme, the{Silver {Studded Blue}and{Grayling.}They have adapted from a heathland to a limestone grassland habitat and are seen from{mid-June}to{mid-July.}The caterpillar of the Blue feeds on the Rock Rose. The Grayling can be seen on rocks and stony ground. Also to be seen are 14 other local-breeding and migrant butterflies.
